newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Heady NZ Telecom may fall after Salomon downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Heady NZ Telecom may fall after Salomon downgrade.

text.p: Telecom Corp of New Zealand's share price may fall after investment house Salomon Brothers downgraded the stock to 'hold' from 'buy' on Tuesday, local brokers warned.
Salomon made its Telecom downgrade recommendation because it said it believed "the upturn in the company's business appears to be moving further into the future".
Dr Don Turkington, managing director of brokerage firm Cavill White Securities, said the market had historically paid close attention to Salomon's appraisal of Telecom.
"They were one of the first international firms to strongly recommend it as a buy some years ago, so their research on Telecom New Zealand is taken account of," he said.
Brokers said Telecom's gains in recent weeks, from NZ$6.62 on May 15 to NZ$6.99 at Tuesday's close, were primarily due to the company's ongoing share buyback programme.
This is taking place both in New Zealand and in the U.S. where Telecom's two largest owners Ameritech and Bell Atlantic are based.
Telecom aims to repurchase NZ$1 billion ($694 million) of its own shares this year in an effort to achieve greater leverage from its capital.
The second of four repurchase periods began shortly after Telecom announced its year profit result on May 14.
"The stock has performed brilliantly well since the buyback started and there's a real unwillingness by institutions to sell into a market when it's been rising do strongly," Turkington said.
"But having said that, it's risen from the low NZ$6.60s to nearly NZ$7.00 over this most recent buyback buyback programme -- there could well be some selling come in."

Both British and U.S. markets were closed on Monday for holidays and brokers said Telecom's recent strong gains, combined with the Salomon report, could trigger a bout of profit-taking when offshore investors return to their offices.
"It has run hard recently," said Tim Koller at Merrill Lynch. "You may well see some profit-taking, and the Salomon Brothers (view) could contribute to that."
Analysts' valuations of Telecom stock currently range from NZ$5.85 to NZ$7.30, another market observer noted. (US$=NZ$1.44)
